long: [ES] A file is a sequence of bytes with metadata like owner and permissions.

short: [ES] Hierarchy used to organize files and directories.
long: [ES] Linux exposes storage as a rooted tree that starts at / and contains mounted devices.

short: [ES] Address to a file or directory.
long: [ES] Paths can be absolute (/var/log) or relative (../src). The shell resolves them based on current directory.

short: [ES] Container that holds files and other directories.
long: [ES] Directories build the tree structure for the filesystem.
[ES] Permissions are defined for user, group, and others and can be set with chmod.
[ES] chown changes ownership. Ownership controls default permission interpretation.

short: [ES] Shared account role used in permissions.
long: [ES] Users can be members of groups to share access to files and services.
[ES] root can bypass many permission checks, so use carefully.

short: [ES] Run a command with elevated privileges.
long: [ES] sudo executes one command as another user (default root), usually after policy checks.

short: [ES] Default permission mask for new files/dirs.
long: [ES] umask removes permission bits from defaults (files 666, dirs 777).

short: [ES] A flow of bytes through stdin/stdout/stderr.
long: [ES] Unix tools read and write streams, making redirection and composition possible.
[ES] Programs read data from stdin by default, often from keyboard or a pipe.
